 I can't speak for lousiana, but the blue streak up the arkansa river is the old industrial section, which is almost all black. The city expended, white folks moved to the burbs, Blacks ended up in the inner city. I would assume the same is true in Louisianna since most cities built on a river start at the river and gorw outwards, leaving the section at the river as the old part of town.

 I am currently living in Nashville. Before that I lived in Natchitoches, La. Before that I lived in Little Rock, Ar. Before that I lived in Ruston, La. before that I lived in Baton Rouge and before that I lived in New Orleans where I was born. Wasn't that lovely?
 
 Louisiana (where I was born and lived until college) has parishes not counties. 
 Looking at this 
 CNN Map I don't see any "streak" I just see a few faint blue spots along population centers. Orleans parish is mostly black and its dark blue. Jefferson Parish (still part of metro New Orleans) and other surrounding parishes are mostly white and is red (gotta love white flight). East Baton Rouge parish, where Baton Rouge is, is red also. This is the next biggest city in La. I think that the slightly blue parishes are just because the election was close. There are a lot of slightly red parishes too. That corridor between Baton Rouge and New Orleans is moslty black or poor whites with funny accents (or folks that are in between, there's a lot of that in La.)
 
 Looking at this 
 CNN Map I don't see a streak going up the Arkansas river. I see one going up the Mississipi. Pulaski county (where Little Rock is) is ever so slightly blue. It says the margin was 55/45 for Kerry. Going up the Arkansas to the west from there I see nothing but red or almost red. Following it down to the southeast toward the Mississippi is turning blue and those areas are majority black.
 
 Ah! and I forgot one thing about southern La. and especially the New Orleans area. It's very much catholic. I doubt that had anything to do with it though.

Going up the Arkansas to the west from there I see nothing but red or almost red. Following it down to the southeast toward the Mississippi is turning blue and those areas are majority black.
 
 Ah! and I forgot one thing about southern La. and especially the New Orleans area. It's very much catholic. I doubt that had anything to do with it though.
You left a beautiful little town in Natchitoches. (Nacka-tush) I used to do a lot of work there at the oil mill. I love the cobble stone street and the Cain River Lake. I stayed at a cabin on the "lake" for weeks at a time for several successive years. One of the best "all-you-can-eat" catfish places is just outside of town and they have the best cole slaw on earth. The college girls were quite a sight, too.
 
 ICBM, but I think Natchitoches is older than New Orleans.
 
 We did a lot of work at New Roads, Louisianna. At the time, there were two real cajuns, father and son, working for us and they took us to a place across the lake to have a beer or two one night. When we got there, the father told us not to say anything at all until he went around to all the tables and told everybody we were "okay". After that, it was like we were part of every family there. The cajuns are very friendly but leery of strangers. 
 
 I spent my first honeymoon and several great vacations in New Orleans.
Dono

 Second that! I have lived and traveled all over this great country, and I found the people of Louisiana to be some of the most friendly and gracious anywhere. I spent four years in Baton Rouge calling on customers throughout the state and I made some great friends ..... as well as having some of the best fish and other seafood on earth.
 Dono

 Oh god, I was so thankful to get the hell out of that godforsaken hole called Natchitoches (yeah, Nak-o-tish). Yes, it's older than NO. It was founded in 1714, the first settlement in the La. territory. It's where Steel Magnolias was filmed and where Jim Croce died. I hated that place with all my soul and never desire to return. I had to leave before I slit my wrists.
 
 Anyway, I don't know where you got the catfish, but that's pretty much La. for you. You're gonna find some catfish so it probably wasn't unique to Natchy. Maybe you liked that place because you didn't have to live there, sorry I don't share any enthusiasm for the place. It's a nice place to visit...
 
 Ah! Except eating at "The Crawfish Hole" which is one of the few places that will serve you fresh boiled crawfish. It's right across the street from the drive through liquor store and daiquiri shop (god I miss La. for those- Tenn. just doesn't do daiquiris and would never sell them at a drive though).
 
 I know New Roads. It's right outside of Baton Rouge. emoticon_cool
 
 I miss a lot of things about La. except the reason I don't live there anymore and that's no jobs. Well, low paying jobs are mostly what you'll find these days. 
 
 Well, anyways, where you at?
pnac=ww3

Second that! I have lived and traveled all over this great country, and I found the people of Louisiana to be some of the most friendly and gracious anywhere. I spent four years in Baton Rouge calling on customers throughout the state and I made some great friends ..... as well as having some of the best fish and other seafood on earth.
 Dono

 You know I hear that a lot, that people from La. are "warm and friendly." You get that from foreigners who don't think you are really american or something. I wonder about this because I don't really have too much of a basis for comparison. I just try not to be an a-hole. Besides, I go other places and people are friendly enough. Hell, I was even getting annoyed when I moved to Nashville and every damned person that passed me had to say hello. (*shrug*)

title: 4Forums.com Political Debates and Polls -  A puzzling pattern!
